I can't lie, I was really impressed when they first opened.  It's HUGE and the sushi selection is amazing, albeit still buffet sushi.

The rest of the food is basically the standard Chinese buffet fare.  Fried and Americanized for our tastes.  My recommendation is to stay away from that and instead get fresh grilled food from the Mongolian bar and a plate of sushi.  Desserts are also pretty standard and probably not worth the calories.

Because hubby isn't a fan of Chinese buffets in general I'm not regularly eating in but rather occasionally stopping there for lunch and do sushi carry-out.  They charge by the pound to do carry-out.  The sushi costs more than the standard buffet food.  I find I can get enough sushi to satisfy my hunger and still pay less than the all you can eat lunch price.

In the end, choose Journey as it is the most palatable of the Chinese buffets in the area.  And if you don't care for Chinese food, it will still work for you with their other options.

I am rating this four stars--keeping in mind that it IS a buffet. If it were a typical  restaurant, it would really only get three. Lets be real, there is a different standard here.

My sister likes non-raw sushi and Chinese buffets, so this was a great place to take her for her birthday. She was quite happy with the meal. I was satisfied--especially given the price.

There were maybe 15 types of rolls out, but a third were filled with "Krab". Not my fave, but she said they were pretty good. Several of the others just had too much goop and just didn't make me want to put it on my plate. The one roll that stood out was the Mango roll--very tasty. The fish was pretty fresh, but many of the rolls were just kind of sloppy, with the over saucing and loose rolling. Even with all of that, it was surprisingly good for less than $15 a person, AYCE. 

My sister was excited about the crawfish, but after reading another review I told her not to get too pumped because she used to live in Louisiana. She actually said they were better than some of the Cajun restaurants she's been to in the area--but could use a bit more kick.

The other buffet items were 80% hit and 20% miss. Most things were fresh and had good flavor(seaweed salad, green beans, chicken skewers). Some were disappointing to see(baked Krab salad with cheese, crab shells stuffed with Krab and cheese, mussels covered in...cheese) and some that were just downright awful(ugh, the cakes!). 

Service was very efficient and friendly, though. 

If I had to choose to eat at a buffet in Madison, this would probably be it.

Don't know what to say. Thought it'd be one of those family bonding buffet dinners but it ended with everyone constipated afterwards and the following morning. Service was very slow and to health standards, the food was horrible. Everything was average tasting or plain at best. To make matters worst, the foods were not changed one bit during the almost 2 hours that we were there. The sushi rice was hard and tasted horrible. Had to tell my folks to stop eating it. The noodles were super dry with no sauce, the sashimi on the rice was discolored, and the place was dirty with no one seeming to want to work. There was one server that was only nice and really engaged my family. Thanks to that server that my review is even 2 stars.

Just went here after reading the review in 77 Square. It was terrific. They have delicious spring rolls, a nice selection of Chinese fare, and classic American (Mac and cheese). Very good value. Great service. Loved the prepared-on-the-spot stir fry along with cucumber rolls.

I was very drawn to this place due to my insatiable hunger for seafood, but it ended up being my downfall. Everything about this place is typical except for the atmosphere and the selection. The place is a LOT nicer looking and feeling than any other Chinese buffet I've been to. The selection is seriously crazy. They have all the normal stuff, plus a huge selection sushi, a large variety of seafood, a few American dishes, and some authentic Chinese dishes. Unfortunately, I hated almost all of it. The Chinese buns with red bean paste were delicious though. I tried everything, but ended up filling up on those. The sushi was dry and a little bland. A few of the specialty roles weren't bad. I tried the chicken feet, that was a really interesting experience that I will not be repeating. Everything was pretty average and ok until I sampled the seafood. I almost immediately felt nauseous. Pretty sure I got food poisoning from something. Of course none of my friends had any of it so they all keep trying to get me to go back. Just the thought of it makes me queasy. I begrudgingly went back once and ate nothing but the red bean buns and potstickers. I hope to never come back here again.

Decent buffet. Cheap buffet prices and came with a large group on a Sunday. There was no lobster the day we came but they had other seafood items (crab and crawfish). There were a ton of buffet items that were constantly refilled and they looked pretty fresh since the place was so busy. They had a hibachi, sushi station, and pho station which was impressive. I never expect high quality, delicate food during buffet outings and so based on this idea, this buffet met my expectations. They had excellent service and always cleared our plates quickly. Would definitely come back if I'm on the area!

Quite possibly the worst Asian buffet I've ever eaten at. 

Very confused because most people eating here are Asian, normally a good sign. And everyone is piling their plates high. But I am not a picky eater and I didn't find one thing that tasted good to me. I love sushi and the sushi here should not be allowed to be called sushi. I am not a fan of seafood like shellfish so there's was a lot I had no interest in on the buffet. But I tried every type of traditional Chinese food dish they had and couldn't take more than a bite of anything. 

Lots of dishes looked good but just tasted awful. And many that were supposed to be hot were downright cold.
I really like the food BUT I REALLY HATE the waitstaff staring at me!  Every time I go they are staring at me! it's creepy.  I finally just had to stop going

Some of the food was pretty good, and I would recommend those items.  However, some of the food tasted bad, like it was old and possibly spoiled. We didn't try the sushi.  I have always worried about the health of raw seafood.  After tasting some of their hot dishes (crab, lobster, squid, and shrimp) that tasted like there was something wrong with them, I am glad we didn't try any sushi.

What was good was the fried chicken and sweet and sour chicken.  I didn't have dessert, but the 3 in our party who did said the cream puffs tasted like the cream was plastic and the puffs were stale.  The cakes tasted old.  The hot tea I had tasted like water.  It was colored, but there was no flavor.

It was a nice place to talk, however.  Although the place is fairly large and it was full, it did not seem noisy at all and we could hear one another well.  While I enjoyed the company, the food will keep me from returning.

Decently good place with decent prices. I especially enjoyed the fact that they had salmon roe here as well, which was a big surprise. The seafood is yummy and their noodle station is quite good. I would come back if I was ever in the area, but probably wouldn't go out of my way to come here.

I was pumped to finally try Journey - I'd seen a lot of good reviews from people I know and my boyfriend is a fan. Plus, with a coupon the lunch buffet sounded like a reasonable price. Maybe I set my hopes too high for a buffet, but I was underwhelmed. 

First, there was a general lack of things I'd expect to find (such as Chinese takeout standards like sesame chicken or General Tso's) - instead there was a very sweet, coconutty chicken. Not bad, but I could only eat a couple of pieces because it was so overwhelmingly sweet. Items were not well-labeled in terms of what was vegetarian and not. I tried a spring roll that ended up having pork in it. The sushi bar only had one veggie option and it comprised cucumber and a little bit of maybe bean curd? Some flat, brown substance. It wasn't bad, but the two pieces I had were enough. I know I'm in the minority wanting veggie sushi but a little variety (sweet potato, avocado, asparagus, etc.) would have been appreciated. Cucumber is just so cheap and seems like a cop-out. 

The buffet is obviously self-serve, but we did have a server for our drinks. My BF and I ended up switching sides of the booth after ordering our sodas (root beer for me, Pepsi for him) and heading to the buffet because I had been facing a window and the glare was bothering me. When my boyfriend ordered a refill he was brought a root beer. He later requested a Pepsi by name and was brought...another root beer. The server was unable to keep track of who ordered what and ignored his verbal request, sticking to which drink had been placed at what seat, regardless of the fact we switched. So bizarre. 

I would give Journey another chance for lunch; the price is low and I think if I went in when planning to go (we stopped in on a whim after a Target run) I'd be hungrier and more open to sampling a wider range. I feel bad wasting food so I try to take only a bite or two of things I'm unsure of, but when you do that with a whole plate you can fill up fast on things that you didn't enjoy. Time to be more strategic!

If you are looking for volume, this may be your sort of place. But can't figure out why the place was so busy. Journey smells slightly fishy and is unkempt. It's the sort of buffet where you walk around trying to figure out what you are willing to eat. 

Even the American style salad bar was iffy. Only two dressings to choose from, Ranch and low cal French. On the plus was there was a choice between iceberg and spinach - but both were past their prime. 

As for the seafood - none of it passed my freshness test by smell - but folks certainly were gobbling up the low quality sushi and oysters.  Everything I sampled had a preprepared highly processed bite and aftertaste to it. 

In short - poor quality food, not much choice or variety for a buffet, so so service and not very clean.

We were here once, and plan on going back.  It was a while ago, perhaps 6 months, but I can tell you that everything was very good.   Many of the 'standard' Chinese Buffet menu items were much better than most Chinese restaurants.   The sushi was good.   I have had worse sushi in so-called sushi restaurants that were not buffet style.   I would say that The Journey's sushi is the best buffet sushi that I have had in Wisconsin, and one of the better sushi places, period.

Prices are reasonable, I had no complaints.  It was exactly what I was looking for in a buffet...fresh, immediate, quick, tasty, affordable.

It's like they took 3 awesome food groups that need to be served fresh and turned them all into buffets that sit out until they taste like death. Blech!

The sushi: first off nigiri should NEVER sit out! The temperature and texture of the fish and rice is imperative for good sushi. The sushi chefs (if you can even call them that because I'm sure they can't get certified serving like that) were working away to keep up yet most things just sat on the table getting hard and unappealing. None of the maki rolls had good flavor and I'm honestly surprised I didn't get sick.

The Chinese: once again a bunch of food, most that is deep fried, just sitting getting hard or soggy depending on what it's not supposed to be. The cat fish was impossible to serve as it was huge fillets filled with bones, the chicken and broccoli was dreadful, and the sweet and sour chicken had lost any sense of what it was. Not to mention the bus boys that come around take any food that's fallen on the counter and PUT IT RIGHT BACK IN THE DISH!! Gross!! How is that at all sanitary?? 

After all of that I didn't bother trying the Mongolian. The selection looked sad and I didn't want to wait for it.

Side note: too many items still had eyes for my liking as well.... O.o 

Even the fortune cookies at the end lacked flavor and tasted stale. I will not be back and I don't recommend giving it a try

Do yourself a favor and do not eat here. It's just not good. The person who showed us our table didn't even speak to us.  Carelessness pretty much sums up the approach here: Cleaned bowls for the buffet line are tossed in a bin next to the line.  There's an ice cream dispenser (which is funny) with a messy bottle of Hershey syrup next to it.  
The food isn't good.  Except for the pho.  Just don't do it.

Go here for a kids birthday party Maybe, but that's the best I can recommend. This place is loud, the food is not changed as much as you would like. The flavors are just kind of mediocre. It is cheaper, and the kids love it. Go here for a cheap night out with a large group.

As with all buffets, Journey is more about quantity than quality. I have to say that the quality here is better than with most buffets. 

Hot bar: They do have a lot of seafood. There's crawfish, stone crab, shrimp (fried and steamed), baked salmon, clams, mussels, and SUSHI. (More on the sushi in a second). The crawfish will make you sad if you've ever had crawfish boil down South, but if not, then you should be fine. The clams are where it's at, IMO. The other stuff was probably boiled and doesn't have a lot of flavor. There's also the usual Chinese buffet items: broccoli chicken/beef, orange chicken, fried rice, lo mein, coconut shrimp, fried scallop (not real scallop! Skip it.), hot and sour soup, etc. The potstickers were a hit for me, but the other items were just ok.

Cold bar: your typical salad bar. There was iceberg mix and spinach leaves, then a bunch of typical salad toppings.

Dessert: I saw that they had individual servings of ice cream, as well as soft serve, jello, typical buffet cake, and bananas with some kind of red sauce.

Sushi bar: Sushi chefs are right behind the sushi buffet making the rolls so it's pretty fresh. As far as rolls go, most of them are ones with "fancy" names filled with cooked ingredients catered towards Americans and covered with sauces. They do have a couple of rolls with raw fish and some nigiri down at the end of the line, if you're lucky. I haven't had any disastrous journeys to the bathroom, so I think it's safe.

Hibachi station: Did not get to try, but they had a decent selection of raw ingredients you could pile in a bowl, hand to a chef, and have it stir-fried for you.

Service: It was packed at 6pm on a Saturday night, but we were seated in about 15 minutes. The waiters are very efficient and are pretty good about filling your water up.

Overall: There's enough variety here that you would probably have to make two trips to try everything they have. Although they have some hits, there are also a lot of misses in terms of dishes. Use your best judgement. For $12.95, you can't do better than this all-you-can-eat buffet.

This is a buffet. I know you aren't looking for a newspaper column critique, so here's the long story short.

Atmosphere: Slightly dirty but not off-putting dirty
Service: Quick, efficient, not warm and friendly but not rude
Prices: OK to maybe a dollar or two too pricey for some
Variety: Above average for Madison
Taste: Slightly below average for buffets for about half their offerings, average for the other half
Trend: Slowly but noticeably getting worse since first coming here a couple years ago but still good enough for right now
Self-loathing level after eating: 50% indifference, 35% glad, 10% regret for not going to an Indian buffet instead, 5% unable to process because your brain is fighting off a food coma

Not very good. Many of the food items had sat on steam tables WAY too long. The crab was horrible. The fried chicken was tasteless. French fries, way undercooked. Green beans undercooked and cold. Unpeeled kiwi fruit.
The place was quite clean, The staff friendly and helpful.
Anyplace that serves General Tsao chicken and crab Rangoon is not at all authentic.

This would be a 4 or even 5 star review if I was rating solely within a "cheap sushi" category.  Really wide selection of rolls, and huge selection of other items like seaweed salad, kimchi (not very spicy), Americanized Chinese staples, dim sum, and even some 100% "please-your-grandma style" American food.  No one was getting anything from the salad bar or the fruits so those secitions looked a little neglected (the rest was being constantly refreshed).

You could take a group with divergent / anti-sushi tastes and they should be fine.  At $8.95 for lunch (weekdays) and even cheaper for kids it's a bargain (they get you on the sodas, though!)  Took my 11 year old and his friend who need to learn to pace themselves when it comes to AYCE sushi (just glad they did not loose it in the car on the way home after inhaling 2 plates waaay to fast...)  My 6 year old had a slice of pizza, some bread, a couple of chicken nuggets, and chocolate ice cream (and loved it).

$15 lunch seafood and Asian buffet on a Sunday!

I absolutely love this place! It's cheap, endless, and... Most importantly, it's the best Japanese sushi and seafood I've had in Madison this far! REAL sushi and sashimi! Also, there's lobster, shrimp, and oysters on the shell! Way better than those overpriced Asian restaurants that leave you spending at least $40 by the end of your 1-2 person meal.

Highly recommend!

I used to love this place.  Came once a week.  Great selection.  Last time i came the toilet in the men's room was overflowing and i had to step in sewage to go to the bathroom.  Today, the AC unit in the front door leaked water on my head as I walked in.  I stood at the Pho counter for 5 minutes with waitress coming and going and no one served me.  Prices going up, quality and service going down.  Is it that hard to not have some sewage or liquid get all over your customers?

Wow!!! Came here once and the prices are very reasonable and the food is amazing! Huge variety of food, Chinese, seafood, sushi, American food. It was delicious. It is high quality food for a buffet and I highly recommend to come here!!

I just do no understand what people see in this place. The Fried Rice is possibly the most bland rice I've ever tried. Crab Ragoons are barely filled, Spring Rolls are extremely greasy, far too many American options to be a "Chinese" restaurant (  such as mac n cheese, hot dogs, french fries that were super soggy), orange chicken has a bad after taste and the desert ( minus the Almond Cookies) aren't great. I am not a fan of sushi so I cannot speak much to that.

I went here under several great reviews from people I know. Tried the food twice and have not changed my opinion of the food. It is just below average. 

Now that Orient House has changed management and have declined in quality of food, I am not sure where to go for great chinese food in Madison anymore. Journey reminds me a lot of China One which I do not like.  

Madison can produce far much chinese food. This is just bad.

This is a very hard place to review because the food is really good, but I can only give it 3 stars. I have been here countless times when I was looking to curb my Asian Food cravings, and it does a superb job at that. It does so well and I eat so much, in fact, that I tell myself I won't eat Chinese food ever again. There is so many choices that can fit any persons favorites. If I would rate this place after my first or 2nd plate, I would definitely give it a 4 star. The only complaint is that the dessert bar is severely lacking due to the fact that Americans like their desserts much sweeter, and this restaurant seems to shift their palate to a more oriental demographic.
the good sushi stir fry service the bad the entree on the buffet lukewarm some were flavorless the good does outwiegh the bad good for lunch

Last night was the second time I've been to Journey Buffet.  What really impressed me was their customer service.  We were a group of 7 adults with 4 children and the staff were very accomodating and quick to bring out the high chairs.  It felt good to be treated well as a customer.  The food was also good and much better than most chinese buffets in Madison.  I would go back with a big group of friends.

Good for Madison. Actually, considering other options I must say its not shabby at all...
Lots of sushi options, various rolls both raw and non-raw. 
Pretty decent.
Chinese food buffet and American options as well. But I never am pleased with the American options... I suppose if you are at Journey, a Chinese buffet, don't expect the best Mac and cheese.

The crab rangoons are delish, they have soup options as well as a grill option. 

They have a self serve ice cream dessert area with other cakes/fruits/pastries.

The price is really cheap considering the options. The taste and quality also is at par with the cost you're paying.

Do not eat here. I ate here once with a work colleague and put it this way within 45mins from being back in the office we both had the full journey end to end. Food tastes ok but instant food poisoning didn't sit to well with me. I have no idea how they stay in business.

Back in the day when I used to breakdance 24/ 7 and take advantage of all the free food provided by student organization events, my homies and I would perform on State Street during Badger football games to make some side money. Once we got enough bills from drunk fans that began their Saturdays with downing 40s at 8 am, we'd blow it all on eating at the buffet in the afternoon. (Because that's what you do when you're beautifully young, constantly hungry, and unaware of this tool called Yelp.) We used to hit up this spot called Taste of Asia on the reg, and even battled with that name in Columbus, Ohio in 2005. Needless to say, buffets have a small place in my heart.

But now I'm grown, I gots some $money, and I haven't been to a buffet since 2010; however, every time I get together with my old friends, I get sort of nostalgic. 

Several months ago, I took a trip out to Madison with my girlfriend and met up with one of my best buds, his wife, and their newborn. He told me about Journey's, and we decided to check the joint out. Would it be like old times?

In comparison to other buffets in Madison, this eatery is much cleaner and larger. And speaking of larger, this buffet looks like if Noah's Ark crashed and everything died inside. Whether it's scarfing down deep-fried prawns, indulging in the sushi and salad stations, or raising glucose levels to a dangerous height with the soft serve ice cream machine, one can live this fantasy at Journey's.

Sadly, all the items there, to me, just taste incredibly bland. It was the first time in while where I actually didn't enjoy eating my food. However, there's only so much one can critique about Journey's since 1) it's a buffet and 2) you're paying less than $20 per person. 

I'm sure buffet lovers will love this place. For me, though, I've moved on and so has my stomach. Thus, I think it's appropriate to give this place a well-deserving A-OK.

I don't know if you had the privilege to try Oysy (sushi and seafood buffet) when it was around, but this is the next best thing and I'll take it. A Chinese, Japanese and 
American buffet at a more affordable price than most other buffets in town. 

You can create your own stir-fry, no need to worry about what sauce to make (they have a sauce they use and it complements whatever you put together). There's also a ton of sushi you can choose from. Their sushi is pretty good for buffet setting, they're better than sushi you'd find at other Chinese buffets but no where near sushi special restaurants (of course). There's a salad bar with more options than you normally see, spicy mussels, seaweed salad, squid salad, kim chee and much more. The list really goes on. 

They claim they have over 200 items at the bar...I guess I need to make frequent trips and get eating, I mean counting.

http://www.getnmahbelly.com/2013/10/the-journey/

First visit. I'm allergic to seafood so I was apprehensiveand deleted trying. My loss. HUGE variety! One of the finest for lovers of Chinese food as well as sushi and seafood.

The waiter gave me 4 orogami animals and was very professional. Very clean restaurant and LOTS of seating

Of the times I visit Madison, Journey's is often one of the places our group of friends finishes off with before we part ways. In a way, you can say that the journey of going to and experiencing Madison is incomplete without visiting Journey. 

Journey has a standard assortment of Chinese Americanised buffet food. The selection is large and plentiful with a focus towards seafood items. There is a section with more deep fried and American dishes that will satisfy your buffet needs. What sets Journey apart from other Chinese buffets is it's dedicated sushi bar with many Japanese American highlights. There is a large assortment of available Maki roll pieces, most made with imitation crab meat or vegetable based for those who shy away from raw fishes. They do have some tempura (Japanese deep fried) rolls and sushi and sashimi pieces as well, though the latter two take a while to restock.

If you're expecting fresh and quality sushi, you won't find it here. The rolls often feel like they've been sitting out for a while and are more chewy than you would normally find among Maki rolls. Maybe this is an indicator of how long the toppings have had to bond with the rolls? The pieces itself weren't abysmal, but weren't giving me any wow. I was left doubly unimpressed by what the sushi bar claimed to be a "Shrimp Tempura Roll" with me being unable to identify the tempura and an absent crunch. Anything tempura or deep fried at the sushi bar is soggy and chewy. The sashimi cuts are as slices as much as someone peeled off fish with a rough knife. The cuts are not similar in size and look very unappetizing, like they were scraped off rather than cut. The rice to fish ratio in the nigiri is often unbalanced and inconsistent as well. Overall, if you have sushi cravings but aren't raving about quality and just the experience, Journey's would be perfect. If you're expecting quality sushi for a cheap price, I'd consider traveling elsewhere. 
Besides the standard Chinese/American fusion selection and sushi bar, the service was fairly well. Plates and drinks were handled frequently and swiftly among the party of 24+ I traveled in. There's also a Pho (popular Vietnamese Noodle soup) bar but I hadn't tried it personally. The ice cream and fruit selection are also standard. 

As a Chinese American buffet, Journey's is a great place to eat for a relatively wallet friendly place. However, as it advertises itself as a Sushi buffet, it largely felt underwhelming. Definitely try this place out, but don't have high expectations.

I came here just to check this place out even though I'm not a super huge buffet fan.

There was a variety of sushi options as well as Chinese food options. The chicken Chinese options were a bit dry but otherwise, it was halfway decent. 

The service was pretty good - the servers were pretty attentive. 

I will be back if I'm in a pinch for a Chinese buffet.

What a great place. Total for two people for dinner was 31.44 with two sodas. I got filled up on sushi and went for some fresh fruit for dessert. The buffet is huge, almost overwhelming with the amount of choices, you will definitely find something delicious to eat. Comfortable setting, good music, clean, the staff was very responsive and friendly. My girlfriend and I will definitely be back for more!! *posted a picture of my dinner* :)

The hot serving trays were hot and the cold serving trays were cold.  Most of the Sushi I tried was great. The Pho was a unique opportunity for this type of restaurant. I even liked the kimchi... it was the first time I've had it in about 10 years. Everything was nicely seasoned. Decent service for as busy as they were.

The first time I went here I actually liked the place...it was inexpensive and seemed to be a good quality spot (Chinese/Japanese/American hybrid) with a couple of opening service kinks to work out. Sadly, the service has improved, yet the quality of cuisine has suffered immensely, & the price-tag has gone up.

The sushi is plentiful and options abundant, however most traditional rolls call for about 1/3 cup of rice per whole roll...their rolls have WAY too much rice (at least 2x normal roll amount) so much that any flavor is overpowered by rice....perhaps they switched  chefs but my most recent visit was ridiculous...if you want to do sushi here I recommend going on the busy, weekend day/nights but definitely not during the week...the only time I recall their sushi being of good caliber was during this time frame..

The hot food is usually stale, underdone, and generally lacking...when crab ran goons are inedible I definitely raise an eyebrow! They do have consistently good items like an assortment of soup, fresh fruit, salad, and a create-your-own grill and my personal go to's like seaweed salad and surprisingly delicious mussels!

For weekends this place gets 3 stars...otherwise...more like 2 simply because service here is always pleasant.
Everything smelled like fish and was room temperature. The interior also has an odd perfumey smell, probably trying to cover up the fish. I have no idea why anyone would choose to eat this food:

Umm. Yeah. Not super delicious. Everything was basically approaching average tasting. It's a lot of food and filled my belly. Nothing was disgusting per se, but everything was basically a little colder than lukewarm. It's deceiving because you can see steam coming out of the trays and I would even dig deeper to get the "fresh" stuff and not the stuff exposed to air, but still not even warm. Even the sushi was just... there. 

If you just want variety, this is the place to go. Just wish it all tasted better.

Huge variety! Love that they also have a pho and hibachi bar. Sushi quality is not bad for buffet. Although I have to say this place overall seems a bit filthier than when it first opened, especially the floor.

You typical Chinese/Sushi buffet. The food was fresh and plentiful. If you're a seafood lover the selection is great!! Accommodates large parties or just one. Staff were friendly and cleared the table rather quickly which I appreciate. Will definitely return!

After reading reviews I had high hopes for this place.  Went here for lunch with a big group.  The only good thing Id say was the fried sushi.  Other than that the food was bland and not flavored very well.  Two stars I guess for the lunch buffet price considering their variety of sushi.

The Journey Sushi & Seafood Buffet (4325 Lien Rd, Madison, WI 53704) is the best buffet in town.  If you like sushi, seafood, or Chinese food this is the place to go.  The food is always fresh and we'll presented.  The hot food is always hot without being dry or overcooked unlike other buffets that keep the food hot by turning up the burners and drying out the food.  I especially like the variety of seafood  from crab to all kinds of shrimp.  They even have oysters on the half shell!  The selection of Chinese food is impressive and very tasty.  Their grill is great and you can select the items you want and they will grill them for you.  The restaurant is very clean with excellent lighting and a large number of booths and tables to select from.  The staff are very friendly and are very attentive to customer needs.  The price is fantastic with dinner at $12.85...WOW!  Try this place and you will be a regular like I am. ENJOY!

This is about what you can imagine when you think of an all you can eat buffet. Great if you're extremely hungry, all you can eat buffet for an incredible price. If you're looking for quality on the other hand, look elsewhere. Food tastes as if it's been sitting out. Things that should be crunchy, are more of a chewy consistency. All in all, not impressed.
There was a wide selection of food, but fried items were soft and chewy, not crisp and food could have been warmer.  Doing a few things well would work better than having so many so-so options.

Journey was my first ever sushi buffet experience. I definitely didn't go into it expecting to be blown away, but I was pleasantly surprised!

The sushi wasn't the best I've ever had by a long shot, but it definitely satisfied my craving and I loved the variety. My husband and I went for their lunch buffet on a Monday afternoon and they must have had 12-15 different rolls up for grabs!

I didn't have much other non-sushi food except for the soft-serve dessert, but they had 4+ other buffet lines with non-sushi offerings.

Journey will definitely do for sushi in a pinch, but I'll probably go to one of the other sushi restaurants in the area for my sushi fix in the future.

We've been going in to this place since they open, our place to go on weekends. Good food and cheap price compare to other buffets in Madison. We've been to most asian and non asian restaurants in Madison and surrounding areas, this place is a keeper. Food is not overly salty, most restaurants can't even taste the food itself.! It's all salty. My fav. Is the fresh Mongolian grill station and Pho station. Would have gave this a 5 star but their ladies bathroom need a ventilation, there is hot water in the restroom, good sign.! it's clean but few times I went to the restroom,smells really bad. It reeks! can't stand it.!  I just don't use the bathroom there at all for how often we eat there on weekends. To the owner. Please put some air freshener in the restroom, have someone clean more often and empty garbage during busy hours. Thanks!

Great selection of seafood and sushi, as the name implies, but that's not all. There was a wide selection of other food as well, so your whole group can find something they like. The price is quite reasonable for what you are getting and the service was attentive and quiet. I Know we'll be back because we couldn't try everything, even though we stuffed ourselves.
Best buffet/restaurant I've been to in awhile.. Food was awesome. Can't wait to go back. Sooo rooting for this place to succeed. Then the east side would finally have a decent place to eat. Love it:)

Sushi wasn't good.. Could be better... Overall chinese food...hmm okay..... 
What i like the most? Pho station!!!!! This alone earns 4 stars from me :)!!!  I was impressed by it and had so much fun having the chef make pho with the toppings I like!!!! I just wish more Chinese buffet places have pho station like this place!

Ate there last night with two of my kids and we were all VERY disappointed with both the food and the service. Some of the buffet items were burnt and cold, some under cooked and warm/cold, and something I brought back on my plate from the salad area was actually spoiled and smelled rancid!!  We used to make it a point to eat at this place and based our last few very unimpressive visits...we've decided to make it a point to ALWAYS avoid this place. There are way too many other really good restaurants in Madison to keep spending money here on bad food and poor service. Bye Journey ...good luck and try NOT to give too many other people food poisoning.

Great selection of food.
Good service.
I love to eat LYCHEE there .
Highly recommend.

Want to get filled up on sushi, and Chinese food?   Here's your place. This building is huge, and there are a couple different dining rooms. The buffet selection is also huge. Plenty of cold salad and fruit offerings, seafood of course, as well as plenty of steaming Chinese entrees and a smattering of American selections. Quality of food and flavors is better than good. Hey, my crab rangoon wasn't soggy,  extra point there...I love that there is a nice variety of sushi displayed on ice, and replenished often, so you can get your sushi fix. Stay in and eat, or fill a to-go box. They will weigh it and charge you according to that.  Dinner price is around $13, and lunch is about $8. Lunch is from 11- 3:30.
I say, stop in and give them a try! You can most definitely get your money's worth during the lunch time!
5 star for many reasons! But I won't tell you any, you have to come and experience  yourself! Hahah

I decided to come here on Mothers Day because a) I am a mother, and b) I like to eat food. Lots of food. I wasn't disappointed, but I wasn't really pleased, either. The price was jacked up for the "holiday" and I think I paid $15 for the buffet, per person, including two preteens, who just ate garlic bread and sugar buns. There is a ton of food here, but a lot of it is weird cheesy seafood casseroles, gloppy Americanized dishes, and questionable crab dishes. 
I ended up eating a lot of breaded shrimp, and some fried rice--the basics. 

I might come here again if I have the hankering to mindlessly eat a large quantity of food, and I don't care much about the quality. Sometimes that's the mood I'm in. But if I'm looking for a Chinese buffet, I won't be going here. Too expensive, and not enough truly good or delicious items on the buffet.

It ain't so bad.

I mean, it's an all-you-can-eat buffet, so don't walk in expecting the moon.  

That being said, it's better than I thought it would be.  The service was good. The food was decent for AYCE. The selections were wide and varied.  I'm not going to hate on this one.

The sushi wasn't the best.  Hy-Vee has better sushi, but for all-you-can-eat, you shut the heck up and eat it.  

The dessert selection was the least impressive thing to me, but even that was okay.  

I will go back.  I'm not in any hurry to go back.  But I will go back.

I've been missing Oysy since it closed. 

Journey is as good or better. Only thing I missed was peel and eat shrimp. Aside from that it has all the expected items at a Chinese buffet such as this. 

Overall quality is terrific, even my wife who doesn't like fried Chinese food enjoyed it. 

Next time I'll try the stir fry in back!

Disgusting buffet style food. What happened to this place?? It used to be so good. First visit in awhile since I live on the other side of town. Strong fish smell when you walk in -- not the fresh fish smell -- more like sitting in a pan for a very long time smell. The food was old and the sushi was crusted. We will never return.

This buffet is epic! I had been meaning to try this restaurant when we got a coupon in the mail. As it turns out the buffet is extremely affordable with or without a coupon. $9 for an adult lunch on a weekday!

The food options on offer seemed endless. There must have been 200+ different items on offer. Everything was included in the base price!

There was a lineup of sushi in front with all the fixings. A couple of chefs were making more rolls right behind the counter. I wouldnt recommend the tempura rolls but all the other varieties were delicious.

Next up was a salad bar with the usual offerings plus a lot of extras like edamame, seaweed salad, broccoli salad, and beady eyed shrimp on ice.

Behind that was a line of dessert offerings complete with ice cream machine. I tried a mini chocolate parfait that was delicate amd flavorful!

Next up was the main course. 5 buffet stations full of warm food. Everything from General Tso's chicken to stuffed mushrooms, fried rice to french fries. There were also a few kid friendly dishes on show. I saw cheese pizza, mac and cheese and chicken strips.

If that weren't enough I was excited to find two made to order options on the back wall. You could make your own mongolian wok or pho soup and they would cook it right in front of you.

Its going to take a couple visits to try everything, but I'm willing to make the sacrifice ;) A special shoutout to the chinese doughnuts that brought me back to my childhood!

Why so many stars people? I'm assuming because it's inexpensive? New to Madison area. Coming from California. So I've tried plenty of Chinese/Asian foods and none were ever as disappointing. Upon entering, the moist smelling, black stained carpets already threw me off. I know Chinese food tastes different when you go to different states. (I've traveled and tasted Chinese food elsewhere. And some say it's because the people are from different areas of China...makes sense!) But I found not one thing I liked here! Not even one! What?! And I'm not a fancy fufu person whatsoever. Lol. Just tasted odd and the fried things tasted like old oil had been used. 
Sadly, will not be returning...ever.

Well, it's not great. It's not terrible. It's also a buffet, where food doesn't tend to taste good, but you get a lot of food for not too much money. If you haven't eaten until you hate yourself, then you didn't do a buffet correctly.

It's nice that they have a variety of food. I wouldn't necessarily come for the seafood though... It's questionable... Seafood shouldn't have that "fish smell." That sounds silly, but if it smells like bad fish or overly fishy, then it is no good.

Highly recommend the fried donuts, because I have no standards and that is my favorite buffet dish.

I do not love the sushi. I do not recommend the sushi. I would definitely go somewhere else for sushi than eat questionable raw sushi. 

Oh. I was semi-annoyed when we had to change tables 3 times because the servers didn't plan accordingly. There were four of us, and they put us at a 6 person table. So, when a 6 person party arrived, we had to move to a 4 person table that just opened up. It's not that big of a deal, but this was after they had already moved us to this second 6 person table because another party wanted to sit at the particular table at which we were sitting.

The food was excellent and offered a huge variety.  Fresh, cold, hot soup, salads, many dishes from pho to sushi to crab.  There was enough variety to keep the younger ones happy- french fries, spaghetti, pizza as well.  Taboes settings for large groups too and conveniently located near East towne mall. 
The price was reasonable for lunch, definitely will come back

Ehm, if you are looking for some quality and tasty sushi, this is not the place for you!
They do have a number of variants, but none is to my taste.... They are just blah *sorry*

But the seafood is okay. If you are craving for some crab, shrimp, fish and other seafood, you can give this place a try.

And will I ever go back? No, not really, unless I really miss having some seafood, which may not happen in the near future. 
As for my sushi fix, I will definitely look elsewhere.

Went for dinner the other night, and we were very pleased.  Hubby loves the sashimi, and ate his fill of it.  I, on the other hand, detest raw fish, and they have a very nice selection of foods for those of us that don't do the sushi/sashimi dealeo.  Rock crab, stuffed crab, garlic lobster, baby clams, and several "Chinese" dishes,  etc.  
We will be back.
